Real question here, I'm not trolling but I'm not sure if this is better asked on a science sub. 

If every new car sold by every manufacturer in 10 year's time was fully electric, and a good proportion of the energy sources were renewable/carbon neutral, what actual tangible effect would that have on global warming? Are we talking reversing, slowing down, maintaining the same rate, or still accelerating but slightly less? 

Some say we've passed the point of no return decades ago, and that the current level of CO2 in the atmosphere will continue to warm the planet to disastrous levels even if all manmade greenhouse gas emissions stopped overnight.

If this is all for naught or too little too late, then I'm struggling to see much of the point of announcing an ICE ban some years in the future other than trying to garner good publicity and provide a false sense of hope.

I'm not even going to mention the enthusiast perspective and nostalgia towards the combustion engine, because that alone has no sway in dictating the direction of the market or policies.

comment:
> Imo. These kinda announcements are just a attempt to boost the stock price since tesla is so overvalued.  

I think it's meant to do something slightly different actually. The problem with legacy auto and EVs is that the transition will necessarily be painful because you have to still make money while funding and getting consumers to buy the new technology. VW is the only big auto to really take that challenge on. So what GM is doing here is using it's major market position to signal to the rest of the industry that 2035 is the date we're all going to quit ICE and go to EVs, which protects them from the risk of having to convince consumers on their own. It also tells legislators to set that as a realistic date to ban the sale of new ICE, further protecting them from negative economics. If you look at existing ICE bans, the UK and other EU countries have already set 2030 as the date, while CA has set 2035. GM sees the writing on the wall and is trying to seize a leadership role.     

Tesla doesn't have to worry about any of this because they don't have a legacy ICE business to manage, nor do they need to worry about investors expecting dividends.

People like me are far from a majority of the market, but are over represented in new car sales. From Dec-April I tend to go skiing 1-3x a week, my ski hill is  75 miles from here. comment:
Horse drawn carriages weren't banned here in Chicago until January 1st, 2021.

Horses aren't viewed today as crude, dirty, unreliable, annoying things; it's still cool to ride on horseback, like out at the woods or something, just extremely impractical.

When electric cars start coming up for sale on the used market in droves for under $2,000, THEN they will be easier to use overall for *everybody* in the population (i.e. not just the upper and upper middle class). But until that day comes... And then there's the charging situation. Many people (in Chicago at least) live in REALLY old two-flat apartments, with no garage. These were built anywhere between 1865 and 1920, and they won't be able to support the electrical load of charging multiple families' cars at once. There will need to be electric stations, similar to gas stations of today, where you can pay a small fee to charge your car, and you can also buy chips, fountain drinks, lottery tickets, etc. that can *fully* charge a car in the same amount of time (or less) than our current gas stations. 

But banning them is something entirely different. Like I said, it's not going to happen in our lifetimes, or our children's life times. Possibly not even their children's. See the horse drawn carriage example above.

comment:
You have to extract metals from the earth to make a battery. Then that battery does it thing without any extra physical materials added to it for hundreds of thousands of miles (and over a million miles with Tesla's newest battery production line). It's a completely different resource demand compared to oil where you have to constantly extract it to keep cars running. I don't have to dump more lithium and cobalt into my car every 300 miles.

Plus, there are ways to extract those materials from old batteries and build new batteries out of them. And if you have a car with a million mile battery pack in it but the frame rusts away after 500k miles that battery pack can be used in a different vehicle or large grid energy storage.

Any time you're manufacturing something you need to mine for materials. The materials needed for batteries are just a far smarter way to utilize the raw material. You can use canvas to paint on. You can also burn the Mona Lisa for warmth in a camp fire. The former is a smarter use of resources. The latter is a huge waste.

comment:
Many of the developed ski hills with large basses may (CO, UT) but most of the Pacific Northwest ones ones are just day trip locations and have minimal development. I just did a quick check of the Seattle area ski spots:

Crystal Mountain: has RV shore power you can theoretically use for $10 if there is no RV in the spot. But every weekend day of the ski season is fully booked for RVs. So functionally 0 there.

Stevens Pass: 2 plugs.

Summit at Snoqualmie: 3 plugs at the hill, 2 at a gas station.

Mt. Baker: 0

Chargers may be cheap to install, but a lot of these places don't have the electrical infrastructure to support that much power currently: some have to kick on the generators for big storms. Not to mention the chargers make clearing the rudimentary dirt parking lots a lot harder for these places so I don't expect rows on rows of chargers. The Model 3 can do the trip, but people get trapped at most of these places 2-3 times a year due to snow, ice storms, blowdowns, or mud slides and have to spend 6+hrs to the whole night in their vehicles and the heating would burn down the batteries a lot faster than a full tank of gas idling. I do see Teslas at the locations, but far less on storm days which tend to be the best for skiing.

I'm not against EVs, but 100% EVs still has some massive hurdles and the EV vs ICE war seems to ignore the compromise that gives the majority of drivers the best of both: PHEVs.

That's exactly what a subsidy is, doesn't have to be a direct payment. Negative externalities are costs of using the product and if they're nor priced in they're subsidized by the taxpayers. This sort of accounting is not controversial in economics, and it's essentially the subject of the 2018 economics Nobel prize. 

If you think the IMF is bullshit I don't know what to tell you, it's a very reliable source for this sort of analysis.
